awd_titl_txt: Mesh-free resolvent analysis for operator-based discovery of large-scale coherent structures: implementation and the example of the stratified wake behind a sphere
awd_abstract_narration:
Flow instabilities and large-scale coherent structures (e.g. vortices) often lead to faster heating and unwanted drag on aerospace vehicles and can be inherent in the formation of weather events such as tropical cyclones.  Predictive physics-based modeling tools for large-scale coherent structures in turbulent flows are needed in computational aeroscience, natural science, and environmental engineering. Novel numerical approaches will be developed to better simulate technical and natural turbulent flows in three-dimensional complex geometries. The goal of the dissemination strategy is to make the numerical tools developed in this project freely accessible to researchers from diverse backgrounds and disciplinary areas. In addition, the new tool will be used in graduate level courses.

This research identifies an opportunity to facilitate high-order accurate resolvent analyses of complex flows as they occur in nature and in engineering. A key-enabler for the proposed methodology is a recent break-through in the computation of mesh-free radial basis function discretization. In contrast to methods that approximate the discrete Jacobian from residual evaluations, the proposed method permits the adjustment of the accuracy of the discretization to arbitrarily high order, uses a mesh-free approach that significantly simplifies the discretization of complex domains and local grid refinement, and works as a stand-alone tool that can be applied to flow data from different numerical or experimental sources. To demonstrate the capabilities of the developed technology, the project investigates the wake flow behind bluff bodies in density-stratified flows. Motivated by the theoretical correspondence between operator-based resolvent modes and empirical modes computed using spectral proper orthogonal decomposition, the research conducts a comparative study of stratified wake physics using both methods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project aimed to develop and implement a mesh-free resolvent analysis method for understanding and predicting large-scale coherent structures in complex fluid flows. The primary goal of the research was to develop a hydrodynamic stability framework using radial basis function-based finite difference (RBF-FD) methods. This goal was successfully achieved, resulting in a high-order, mesh-free computational framework capable of simulating complex fluid flows with high accuracy and stability.

A significant outcome of the project was the development of a high-order mesh-free hydrodynamic stability tool. This tool utilized RBF-FD PHS+poly discretizations to construct discrete linearized Navier-Stokes and resolvent operators on scattered nodes. It enabled accurate and stable discretization of large matrix problems, facilitating the analysis of flow instabilities in complex geometries. The tool was validated through various hydrodynamic stability methods, including linear stability analysis (LST), resolvent analysis (RA), and wavemaker analysis (WM). These validations included the analysis of cylinder flows at different Reynolds numbers, Blasius boundary layers, and high-Reynolds-number transonic jets.

Building on this, the project also developed a semi-implicit fractional-step Navier-Stokes solver, which uses a staggered node layout. This solver combines the ease of implementation and high order of accuracy of finite difference methods with the geometrical flexibility of finite volume, finite element, and discontinuous Galerkin methods. The solver was validated through benchmark problems, including internal flow in a lid-driven cavity and external flow around a cylinder. These validations demonstrated that the solver could achieve accurate and stable simulations at significantly lower resolutions than previously possible, making it a powerful tool for high-fidelity simulations of engineering and natural flows in complex domains.

This project has broader impacts both in terms of advancing scientific knowledge and providing practical tools for the engineering and scientific communities. The mesh-free RBF-FD Navier-Stokes solver addresses a crucial need for accurate and flexible computational methods capable of handling complex geometries and flow conditions. This tool has the potential to be applied across various fields, including aerospace engineering, environmental science, and oceanography, where understanding fluid dynamics is essential.

The project's findings have been disseminated widely through multiple high-profile conferences and publications, ensuring that the advancements reach a broad audience. Additionally, two significant papers were published in the Journal of Computational Physics, detailing the development and validation of the RBF-FD discretization method and the application of mesh-free methods for hydrodynamic stability analysis. Throughout the life of the award, the project achieved several key outcomes. The development of a robust and flexible RBF-FD discretization method for solving the Navier-Stokes equations facilitated high-fidelity simulations of complex fluid flows. The new computational framework was rigorously tested and validated against benchmark problems, proving its accuracy and stability. It was applied to various fluid dynamics problems, including the analysis of cylinder wakes and boundary layers. The project's results were shared with the scientific community through conference presentations and journal publications, enhancing the visibility and impact of the research.

A change in the project's direction occurred during its course. While the initial focus was on applying hydrodynamic stability analysis to stratified flows, the research shifted towards developing a comprehensive incompressible RBF-FD Navier-Stokes solver. This decision was motivated by the realization that the new tool would have a broader and more significant impact on the field of computational fluid dynamics. The development of the Navier-Stokes solver, which was not part of the original proposal, has already demonstrated significant benefits, providing a unified computational framework that can handle both the simulation of base flows and the subsequent hydrodynamic stability analysis using a single tool chain.
